questions.question_text: A network technician is working on a proposal for email migration from an on-premises email system to a vendor-hosted email in the cloud. The technician needs to explain to management what type of cloud model will be utilized with the cloud-hosted email. Which of the following cloud models should the technician identify in the proposal?

discussion.content:
SaaS (software as a service) allows users to connect to cloud-based apps such as email, calendars, and other office-type automation tools. 

The question indicates the technician’s proposal is for “vendor-hosted email in the cloud.” Vendor-hosted email in the cloud is considered a SaaS.

Compared to the other answers, the only one that I see that would be somewhat relevant would be Software as a service (SaaS), which is a software distribution model in which a cloud provider hosts applications and makes them available to end users over the internet. Which is basically what's happening in this scenario.
can someone explain this answer pls

comments.content: My reasoning behind it was that email service providers typically already have an application they use like Office 365, and the only thing you provide is your data. Thus, a SaaS.

discussion.content: can someone explain why the answer is C?

comments.content: "Vendor-hosted" means that the email app is fully managed by the vendor. SaaS - Software-as-a-Service is a ready-to-use solution (e.g. Office365, G Suite etc.).

discussion.content: note : testing and research purposes for the LAB, best place in DMZ to segment it from internal network could cause issuses. C and D are void because of the nature of the question.. think logically all the time with these questions "best bet"
DMZ is where you put lightly restricted network......as it is an experimental lab, IMO it will not be accessed by so many people but only by junior team

comments.content: b0ugi3, I concur with you. However, it's the best answer. VoIP is normally configured in VLAN to separate voice from data traffic.

discussion.content: Why would you put an experimental lab in a DMZ where outisders can access it?

choices.B: The technician should put the junior team's lab in a DMZ and the phone system in a VLAN.
choices.A: The technician should put the junior team's lab in a VLAN and the phone system in the DMZ.
choices.C: The technician should put the junior team's lab in the LAN and the phone system in the WAN.
choices.D: The technician should put the junior team's lab in the WAN and the phone system in a WLAN

questions.question_text: A senior technician is reconfiguring the company's firewall because a number of additional devices have been added to the network. The company has acquired a new VoIP phone system, and a group of junior technicians has set up an experimental lab with access to the Internet. Management has given the team latitude for research and development, but would like the company network to be secure and the performance to remain consistent with existing baselines. Which of the following would be the BEST method to reconfigure the network?

A network technician discovers there is no connectivity on a T1 line even though the cable connection appears to be in place. The router shows there is no active connection on the port. The issue is occurring between the demarcation point and the router port. The router cable tests fine and is terminated at the demarcation panel. Which of the following tools should be used to fix the issue?

discussion.content:
"The issue is occurring between the demarcation point and the router port. The router cable tests fine and is terminated at the demarcation panel."

Therefore, if there is nothing wrong with the cable and it is terminated at the demarc, why is it necessary to use a punchdown tool? We are also told that the issue relates to the section between the demarc and router port. In my humble opinion, the answer is (D) Loopback adapter.

The loopback adapter can be used to test the CSU/DSU (Channel Service Unit/Data Service Unit) that is located between the router (or DTE device) and WAN link.
Loopback and OTDR are used to find out the issue, not fix the issue

I believe the answer is D: Loopback adapter. A loopback test is a diagnostic procedure where a signal is transmitted and returned to the sending device after passing through ALL OR A PORTION of the network or circuit. That returned signal is compared to the transmitted signal to evaluate the integrity of the equipment OR transmission path.

comments.content:
Because the problems are at the demarcation PANEL, i.e. the punchdown panel, which requires a punchdown tool.

CompTIA will use wordplay to confuse you, best of luck on the network+!
he needs to FIX the issue.

discussion.content: Why is not a OTDR or Loopback adapter

The answer is most likely (D) Loopback adapter.
"Although you can do both software and hardware loopback tests on a CSU/DSU, a loopback plug is more effective to isolate problems. A software loopback towards the router usually only loops the DSU functionality of a CSU/DSU. A hardware loopback is able to prove that the entire CSU/DSU is not at fault."

CSU/DSU (Channel Service Unit/Data Service Unit) Explainer:
"A CSU/DSU (channel service unit/data service unit) is a digital-interface device used to connect data terminal equipment (DTE), such as a router, to a digital circuit, such as a Digital Signal 1 (DS1) T1 line. The CSU/DSU implements two different functions. The channel service unit (CSU) is responsible for the connection to the telecommunication network, while the data service unit (DSU) is responsible for managing the interface with the DTE.

A CSU/DSU is the equivalent of the modem for an entire LAN. The DCE, commonly a modem or CSU/DSU, is the device used to convert the user data from the DTE into a form acceptable to the WAN service provider transmission link."
You need the need to physically punch-down the cable for conductivity. "demarcation ' is the key word.
Logical network separation is also known a VLAN, and 802.1Q is the IEEE standard that enables trunking.
